q: What are the symptoms of postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS)?
a: The symptoms of PoTS include dizziness or light-headedness, fainting or almost fainting, noticeable heartbeats (heart palpitations), chest pain, shortness of breath, shaking and sweating. Other symptoms may include problems with digestion, headaches, weakness, and problems with thinking and memory.

q: What can make the symptoms of postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS) worse?
a: Certain factors such as feeling hot, eating refined carbohydrates, not drinking enough fluids, drinking alcohol, resting too much, exercising, and being on your period can worsen the symptoms of PoTS.

q: How is postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS) diagnosed?
a: To diagnose PoTS, a GP may check your blood pressure and heart rate before and after you stand up. If necessary, you may be referred to a specialist who may perform additional tests, including blood tests, urine tests, and heart and blood pressure tests.

q: What treatments are available for postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS)?
a: Treatment options for PoTS may include lifestyle changes, such as regular eating and drinking, stress management, and trying different medications like beta blockers, steroids, and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).

q: What can I do to ease the symptoms of postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS)?
a: If you have PoTS, you can try lying down and raising your legs when you feel faint or dizzy. You can also try crossing your legs, rocking up and down on your toes, clenching your buttocks and tummy muscles, and clenching your fists. Additionally, making lifestyle changes like avoiding triggers, staying hydrated, doing gentle exercise, and wearing support tights can help.

q: Where can I find more information about postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS)?
a: You can find more information about PoTS on the PoTS UK website. Another resource is STARS (Syncope Trust And Reflex anoxic Seizures), which provides information on postural tachycardia syndrome.

q: What are the treatments available for postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS)?
a: The treatment for PoTS may involve making lifestyle changes, managing stress, trying different medicines or combinations of medicines like beta blockers, steroids, and SSRIs.

q: What can individuals do to alleviate symptoms of PoTS?
a: Individuals with PoTS can try lying down and raising their legs when feeling faint or dizzy. Other techniques include crossing legs, rocking up and down on toes, clenching muscles, avoiding triggers, staying hydrated, engaging in gentle exercise, elevating the head of the bed, and wearing support tights.

q: What lifestyle changes can help with PoTS?
a: To manage PoTS, it is advised to avoid triggers, drink plenty of fluids until urine is pale, engage in gentle exercise, raise the head of the bed, and wear support tights to improve blood flow.

q: Can other conditions cause symptoms similar to PoTS?
a: Yes, symptoms similar to PoTS can be caused by other conditions such as low blood pressure. Hence, experiencing such symptoms does not guarantee a diagnosis of PoTS.

q: Is postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS) a sudden or gradual development?
a: PoTS can develop suddenly or gradually over time. The severity of symptoms can vary, and they may change from day to day.

q: Can postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS) have a big impact on daily life?
a: Yes, for some people, PoTS can have a significant impact on their everyday lives. It may affect their ability to perform daily activities and may cause weakness, fatigue, and difficulty with exercise and sleep.

q: When should I see a doctor if I suspect I have postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS)?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of PoTS. They can evaluate your symptoms and provide appropriate guidance or refer you to a specialist if necessary.
